The Mayor of London spoke to the capital’s 18- to 25-year-olds at our YPM event about how they can shape the city’s future Wednesday 25 January 2017 18:56 BST Click to followES Lifestyle Sadiq Khan speaking at the YPM event Lucy Young 
Mayor of London Sadiq Khan has today spoken out about the importance of making sure the voice of young London is heard. 
Speaking at the Evening Standard’s Young Progress Makers event, Khan told the capital’s under-25s: “I see every day how young Londoners boost the economy and unleash creativity with passion and excitement.” 
“You will shape the future, so it’s important that we unlock the potential of the next generation.” 
Addressing the audience at The Roundhouse, the Mayor pledged to help ensure that young Londoners can achieve their goals by providing affordable rents and transport that “doesn’t break the bank.” 
“There has never been a more exciting time to be a young Londoner,” said the Mayor, referencing the recent expansion of Google, Facebook, Apple and Snapchat in the capital. Lily Cole warns young Londoners: You are the future of the internet 
Leading a discussion on power in London, he continued: “History tells us that young londoners with big ideas can achieve extraordinary things.” 
The Mayor called upon John Boyega, Adele and Good Chance Theatre creators Joe Murphy and Joe Robertson as stellar examples of young Londoners who have achieved great things. 
“I’ll never be as cool as them,” he joked, “but as someone who is the child of an immigrant, brought up on a council estate, 5 ft 6 and the Mayor of London, anything is possible.” 
The Mayor was joined by designers, entrepreneurs, tech innovators and politicians to discuss the challenges facing young people at the Evening Standard's Young Progress Makers event. 
Discussions centred on the themes of power, possibility and performance. Humza Arshad: Don’t jump on a trend because it’s popular on YouTube 
Among those speaking today were ex-Olympics minister Tessa Jowell, YouTube star Humza Arshad and Kate Unsworth, whose firm Vinaya combines high-fashion jewellery and hi-tech design. 
Evening Standard editor Sarah Sands said: “The Young Progress Makers day is a chance for our youth to solve the challenges of this city — they may well do a better job than the rest of us. We reckon we can identify a sensibility for the capital — entrepreneurial, optimistic, creative, socially responsible. 
“The YPM Day should be inspiring, fun and I hope will produce brilliant ideas that could become realistic policies. We intend to create a network from which jobs and friendships should flow. Last time we held a much smaller-scale forum such as this, a speaker came up with the idea of a Night Tube, which was taken up by Transport for London. We can improve London, and the YPMs are the people to do it.”
